title: The Chronicals of Narnia: The Lion, the With, and the closet
content:
OMG!!! I saw the greatest movie ever made... and on opening day!

I saw the first showing available in Wisconson, U.S.A. on a class field trip.

I have been helping in the Computer Lab, and so the headmaster said he'd do anything in return...

I chose school field-trip.

Grades 4-8th (sadly only 22 kids...) went to see Narnia.

It was sooo awesome; and made LOTR shake in it's shadow...

I highly recomend this movie!!!

[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Tough Guys Can Fix Their Own Problems!!!

title: Nifty Looking.
content:
Looks like an awesome movie. Has a similar feel to Myst (more the novels and Exile, than Myst/Riven/Uru, though) which immediately makes me want to see it.

I don't know where you pulled that reference to 'all good Christians' thing. I haven't heard anything about that in the trailer. I don't see why you seem to give such people so much power over your decisions anyway... doing the opposite of what someone says without making up your own mind is just as sheepy as doing exactly what they say.

Btw... closet?[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-confused.gif[/img] I believe it's Wardrobe. I'll let the 'With' typo slide for the moment. Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

A concerned member of the Preservation of Endangered Spleens Society

[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/]JimSoft Lair[/url]

title: Re: Nifty Looking.
content:
"I don't know where you pulled that reference to 'all good Christians' thing."
Indeed. Perhaps from some ultra-Catholic magazine.

"I don't see why you seem to give such people so much power over your decisions anyway... doing the opposite of what someone says without making up your own mind is just as sheepy as doing exactly what they say."
Indeed, and it's highly ironic in this case.

But I can understand perfectly if someone doesn't want to see this.. It just sounds so boring.. (And looks.) Only good thing is that big lion I saw in the trailer, but I don't want to see this just because of him/it. I can't stand these fantasy movies, why don't they make some unique sci-fi such as 2001: Space Odyssey?!? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-furious.gif[/img] I've had enough of some mystical wardrobes or such some group of kids uses to enter some stupid fantasy realm.Eat your veggies!

title: Re: Nifty Looking.
content:
The film is, in fact, a "supposal" of Jesus Christ and his life (incarnation, passion and ressurection), with Alsan being Jesus in the form of a lion. According to the author himself, the book is strongly linked to Christianity.

title: Re: Nifty Looking.
content:
i saw it. it was a fun watch.

[quote]Quote:[hr]It was sooo awesome; and made LOTR shake in it's shadow...[hr][/quote]

no one please pay attention to this statement, it is perhaps the most ignorant thing ive ever heard come out of Najawa's mouth. This is no where near LOTR.

The movie was decent, but was not without flaw. Special effects were 2nd rate (they withdrew me from the story), pacing was a little odd, the white witch didnt really do it for me. I enjoyed it, but this is not high art and you should not go seeing it expecting it to be better than Lord of the fricken Rings which are pretty much my favorite movies.

And as far as the Christianity, if you dont like it dont watch it with that mentality and it wont be very noticable... they dont preach to you and stuff.[img]http://www.denness.net/rpi/username/mr12000[/img]

title: hum
content:
Approaching it from the perspective of a person neither religious or versed in the novel, I thought it was a tale full of imagination but very little development. The older sister was nothing but a nag for the entirety of the film, and the older brother really didn't do anything but enable the younger sister to drag the entire cast deeper into Narnia.

I enjoyed the special effects, as Hollywood is definitely becoming better at integrating live-action with CG... but there were still holes and giveaways, and I can't say I really liked this movie nearly as much as I enjoyed the remake of King Kong.

title: Narniuhh...
content:
Just saw it this evening. Very enjoyable movie, but somewhat lacking. I didn't find it to be anywhere near as classy as Lord of the Rings, especially the first time around. So many things seemed completely arbitrary, the plot jolted around alot, and some things bordered on gimmicky (which is the one main thing that deters me from many, many movies).

As well, that certain feeling elicited by a good fantasy movie (unable to describe it, I can only hope others experience it also) only showed up for me a couple of times, and was quickly stamped out. LotR was laced with it from start to finish.

Add to all this that the ending was underdeveloped. If I had lived 15-20 years in a land underpinned with pure magic and then suddenly reverted to my childhood, I'd be a very different kid than I had been prior to the adventure.

Narnia is an awesome place, and I loved the way time was so intermingled, with seasons transitioning in the blink of an eye, but the movie failed to capture the full spirit of the place. The battle scene came close, but it ended up like a failed sneeze (not so bad if you're not fond of sneezing, but I love it). Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

A concerned member of the Preservation of Endangered Spleens Society

[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/]JimSoft Lair[/url]

title: Re: Narniuhh...
content:
I saw this movie in the cinema a while back, and its OK, but very much a children's movie.
I think the "underdeveloped" used earlier is what I'm talking about as well.
The Turkish delight being something obvious in Narnia, Mr Numbnuts... Humpus... something... being scared like that, the part about what the stone table was exactly... it just didn't make enough sense to me.
That kind of story development was good when I was a child, or still is when I'm dreaming (always random stuff happening in those), but it just left me wanting a bit more.Retodon8
You live, you die, you are remembered, you are forgotten. [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Graphics/Keen_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: Narniuhh...
content:
You'd think with my name "narnia4" it would be my favorite movie or something (narnia4 wasn't supposed to be my user name anyway, but I made a mistake.) Anyway I pretty much agree with everything commanderspleen said. It's basically a kid movie (as it goes far out of its way to not show any blood) even more kiddish then the books. It can't be as good as LotR because it was written for kids.
AS for the Christian elements, they dont portray them nearly as strong as they do in the books, and you don't really see it in the movie unless you look for it. It was pretty obvious Disney made the movie because of the popularity, not the Christian allegorical stuff.
